title: Newtons second law - finding the missing force

content.question: A <math alttext="0.5 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.5</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></math> object with three constant forces exerted on it has an acceleration <math alttext="a equals 28.2 meters per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>28.2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math> at an angle of <math alttext="45 degrees" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msup><mn>45</mn><mo>∘</mo></msup></mstyle></math> above the horizontal as shown in the figure. Two of the forces are given as <math alttext="F sub 1 equals 5 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mtext> N</mtext></math> and <math alttext="F sub 2 equals 30 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn><mtext> N</mtext></math> with directions as shown. What is the magnitude of the third force?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
